node.title: Material Property defined on non-uniform channel
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'm currently creating a multiphysics simulation between Griffin-HT-THM. For the THM I'm creating a coarse model that models the core as a single channel approximation. Due to the geometry of the core, the fuel and thus q_wall discretization requires a non-uniform axial discretization. In HT, the q_wall is computed as a UserObject using LayeredSideAverage for three regions which are the lower, middle and upper. I then transfer these into THM under the names q_wall_lay1, q_wall_lay2 and q_wall_acmdz, where the THM model is setup in the following way:
[Materials]
  [f_mat]
    type = ADWallFrictionFunctionMaterial
    f_D = f_D
    function = 0.0194
  []

  [Re_mat]
    type = ADReynoldsNumberMaterial
    block = 'channel:lay1 channel:acmdz channel:lay2'
    Re = Re
    D_h = 0.0029
    mu = 0.0001582
    vel = 0.6119
    rho = 669.92
  []

  [Pr_mat]
    type = ADPrandtlNumberMaterial
    block = 'channel:lay1 channel:acmdz channel:lay2'
    cp = cp
    mu = mu
    k = k
  []
  [Nu_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    block = 'channel:lay1 channel:acmdz channel:lay2'
    # Dittus-Boelter
    expression = '0.021 * pow(Re, 0.8) * pow(Pr, 0.4)'
    property_name = 'Nu'
    material_property_names = 'Re Pr'
  []
  [Hw_mat]
    type = ADConvectiveHeatTransferCoefficientMaterial
    block = 'channel:lay1 channel:acmdz channel:lay2'
    D_h = D_h
    Nu = Nu
    k = k
  []
  [T_wall_lay1]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wall_lay1
    block = 'channel:lay1'
  []
  [T_wall_acmdz]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wall_acmdz
    block = 'channel:acmdz'
  []
  [T_wall_lay2]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wall_lay2
    block = 'channel:lay2'
  []
[]

[Components]
  [channel]
    type = FlowChannel1Phase
    position = '0 0 0'
    orientation = '0 0 1'

    A = ${A_flow}
    D_h = ${hydraulics_diameter}
    length = '${lay1} ${acm_dz} ${lay2}'
    n_elems = '1       8         1'
    PoD = '${pd_ratio}'
    axial_region_names = 'lay1 acmdz lay2'
  []

  [inlet]
    type = InletMassFlowRateTemperature1Phase
    input = 'channel:in'
    m_dot = ${mdot}
    T = ${inlet_T}
  []

  [outlet]
    type = Outlet1Phase
    input = 'channel:out'
    p = ${outlet_P}
  []

  [ht_ext]
    type = HeatTransferFromExternalAppHeatFlux1Phase
    flow_channel = channel
    P_hf = '${P_wet_core}'
  []
[]

My question is how would I apply the heat fluxes on those blocks explicitly? In a previous easier model I had made with only one heat flux transferred to thm applied uniformly through the channel via Materials, and with a single channel with uniform discretization my methodology was essentially the same. When I run this simulation I get the following error:
�[36mGriffin_htm0_thm0: �[31mMaterial property 'q_wall_lay1', requested by 'T_wall_lay1' is not defined on block channel:lay1
�[36mGriffin_htm0_thm0: �[31mMaterial property 'q_wall_acmdz', requested by 'T_wall_acmdz' is not defined on block channel:acmdz
�[36mGriffin_htm0_thm0: �[31mMaterial property 'q_wall_lay2', requested by 'T_wall_lay2' is not defined on block channel:lay2

For reference this is what my simpler model looked like:
[Materials]

  [f_mat]
    type = ADWallFrictionFunctionMaterial
    f_D = f_D
    function = 0.0194
  []

  # Wall heat transfer closure (all important is in Nu_mat)
  [Re_mat]
    type = ADReynoldsNumberMaterial
    block = channel
    Re = Re
    D_h = 0.0029
    mu = 0.0001582
    vel = 0.6119
    rho = 669.92
  []

  [Pr_mat]
    type = ADPrandtlNumberMaterial
    block = channel
    cp = cp
    mu = mu
    k = k
  []
  [Nu_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    block = channel
    # Dittus-Boelter
    expression = '0.021 * pow(Re, 0.8) * pow(Pr, 0.4)'
    property_name = 'Nu'
    material_property_names = 'Re Pr'
  []
  [Hw_mat]
    type = ADConvectiveHeatTransferCoefficientMaterial
    block = channel
    D_h = D_h
    Nu = Nu
    k = k
  []
  [T_wall]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wall
  []
[]

[Components]
  [channel]
    type = FlowChannel1Phase
    position = '0 0 0'
    orientation = '0 0 1'

    A = ${A_flow}
    D_h = ${hydraulics_diameter}
    length = ${unit_cell_height}
    n_elems = ${num_layers_for_THM}
    PoD = '${pd_ratio}'
    
  #  heat_transfer_geom = hex_rod_bundle
  []

  [inlet]
    type = InletMassFlowRateTemperature1Phase
    input = 'channel:in'
    m_dot = ${mdot}
    T = ${inlet_T}
  []

  [outlet]
    type = Outlet1Phase
    input = 'channel:out'
    p = ${outlet_P}
  []

  [ht_ext]
    type = HeatTransferFromExternalAppHeatFlux1Phase
    flow_channel = channel
    P_hf = '${P_wet_core}'
  []
[]

Any insight on this would be helpful, thank you so much!

Hello

�[36mGriffin_htm0_thm0: �[31mMaterial property 'q_wall_lay1', requested by 'T_wall_lay1' is not defined on block channel:lay1

This means that T_wall_lay1 is expecting a material property, not a variable.
So if you are transferring q_wall_lay1 to a variable, you need to use a ParsedMaterial to convert it to a material property
I think there are dedicated heat transfer objects "from multiapp" that you may want to try out
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
I looked for these heat transfer objects you suggested and I did not find what you were suggesting. In both the 'Transfers' and 'MultiApp' syntax search on the moose documentation, I didn't see that there was anything unique for the heat transfer app. If I'm mistaken then I'd be happy to look again if you can point me to the right direction.
Following your suggestion I made auxvariables for the three different heat fluxes seen here:
[AuxVariables]
.
.
.
  [q_wall_lay1]
    family = monomial
    order = constant
  []
  [q_wall_acmdz]
    family = monomial
    order = constant
  []
  [q_wall_lay2]
    family = monomial
    order = constant
  []
[]

Which are transferred from my heat transfer input as seen here:
[UserObjects]
   [q_wall_avg_lay1]
       type = LayeredSideAverage
       boundary = '${clad_outer}'
       variable = flux

       # Note: make this to match the num_elems in the channel
       direction = z
       num_layers = 1

       direction_min = 0.0
       direction_max = '${lay1}'
 []
 [q_wall_avg_acmdz]
       type = LayeredSideAverage
       boundary = '${clad_outer}'
       variable = flux

       # Note: make this to match the num_elems in the channel
       direction = z
       num_layers = 8

       direction_min = '${lay1}'
       direction_max = '${fparse acm_dz * 8}'
   []
   [q_wall_avg_lay2]
       type = LayeredSideAverage
       boundary = '${clad_outer}'
       variable = flux

       # Note: make this to match the num_elems in the channel
       direction = z
       num_layers = 1

       direction_min = '${fparse lay1 + (acm_dz * 8)}'
       direction_max = '${fparse lay1 + (acm_dz * 8) + lay2}'
   []  
[]

[Transfers]
   [q_wall_lay1_to_thm]
     type = MultiAppGeneralFieldUserObjectTransfer
     variable = q_wall_lay1
     to_multi_app = thm
     source_user_object = q_wall_avg_lay1
   []
   [q_wall_acmdz_to_thm]
       type = MultiAppGeneralFieldUserObjectTransfer
       variable = q_wall_acmdz
       to_multi_app = thm
       source_user_object = q_wall_avg_acmdz
   []
   [q_wall_lay2_to_thm]
       type = MultiAppGeneralFieldUserObjectTransfer
       variable = q_wall_lay2
       to_multi_app = thm
       source_user_object = q_wall_avg_lay2
   []
[]

You'll note that I used the GeneralFieldUserObjectTransfer as the heat fluxes are computed using UserObjects. Now that the UserObjects are passed on to the auxvariables, I then create a ParsedMaterial which I then feed into the wall temperature:
[Materials]
.
.
.
[q_wall1]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'q_wall'
    coupled_variables =  'q_wall_lay1'
    expression = 'q_wall_lay1'
  []
  [q_wallacm]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'q_wall'
    coupled_variables =  'q_wall_acmdz'
    expression = 'q_wall_acmdz'
  []
  [q_wall2]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'q_wall'
    coupled_variables =  'q_wall_lay2'
    expression = 'q_wall_lay2'
  []
  [T_wall_lay1]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wall1
    block = 'channel:lay1'
  []
  [T_wall_acmdz]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wallacm
    block = 'channel:acmdz'
  []
  [T_wall_lay2]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wall2
    block = 'channel:lay2'
  []
[]

However, I'm still getting the same error as last time. I feel that this should be a relatively easy solution but it's unclear to me what I'm doing incorrectly.

If you are getting the exact same error, then you forgot to change the name from the variable name q_wall_lay to the material property name, which is q_wall here
I am surprised you are not getting an error from this
[q_wall1]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'q_wall'
    coupled_variables =  'q_wall_lay1'
    expression = 'q_wall_lay1'
  []
  [q_wallacm]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'q_wall'
    coupled_variables =  'q_wall_acmdz'
    expression = 'q_wall_acmdz'
  []

this defines the q_wall property all over the domain, from 2 materials. You would need to block restrict these definitions to make this valid

Hi Guillaume,
I'm sorry I'm having trouble with this and I appreciate you patience. I followed what I understood were your suggestions:
[Materials]
.
.
.
  [q_wall1]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    coupled_variables =  'q_wall'
    expression = 'q_wall_lay1'
    block = 'channel:lay1'
  []
  [q_wallacm]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    coupled_variables =  'q_wall'
    expression = 'q_wall_acmdz'
    block = 'channel:acmdz'
  []
  [q_wall2]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    coupled_variables =  'q_wall'
    expression = 'q_wall_lay2'
    block = 'channel:lay2'
  []
  [T_wall_lay1]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wall1
    block = 'channel:lay1'
  []
  [T_wall_acmdz]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wallacm
    block = 'channel:acmdz'
  []
  [T_wall_lay2]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wall2
    block = 'channel:lay2'
  []
[]

I believe that this should resolve both the block restriction issue and the variable naming issue as I now block restrict the ParsedMaterial and also rename the coupled_variables to q_wall. However, I'm now getting the following issue:
*** ERROR ***
Invalid function
q_wall_lay1
q_wall
in ParsedMaterialHelper.
Syntax error: Unknown identifier�[39m

I think you want something like
  [q_wall2_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    coupled_variables =  'q_wall'
    expression = 'q_wall' # expression uses the variable
    property_name = 'q_wall_lay2'
    block = 'channel:lay2'
  []

Following your suggestion:
[Materials]
.
.
.
  [q_wall1]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'q_wall_lay1'
    coupled_variables =  'q_wall'
    expression = 'q_wall'
    block = 'channel:lay1'
  []
  [q_wallacm]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'q_wall_acmdz'
    coupled_variables =  'q_wall'
    expression = 'q_wall'
    block = 'channel:acmdz'
  []
  [q_wall2]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'q_wall_lay2'
    coupled_variables =  'q_wall'
    expression = 'q_wall'
    block = 'channel:lay2'
  [T_wall_lay1]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wall1
    block = 'channel:lay1'
  []
  [T_wall_acmdz]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wallacm
    block = 'channel:acmdz'
  []
  [T_wall_lay2]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wall2
    block = 'channel:lay2'
  []
[]

I am back to this issue:
�[36mGriffin_htm0_thm0: �[31mMaterial property 'q_wall1', requested by 'T_wall_lay1' is not defined on block channel:lay1
�[36mGriffin_htm0_thm0: �[31mMaterial property 'q_wallacm', requested by 'T_wall_acmdz' is not defined on block channel:acmdz
�[36mGriffin_htm0_thm0: �[31mMaterial property 'q_wall2', requested by 'T_wall_lay2' is not defined on block channel:lay2

property name is q_wall_lay1 not q_wall1. So in the Material you need to refer to q_wall_lay1.
q_wall1 is still the name of a variable
ah I see, I now have it working thank you so much!

node.title: How to properly access variables and aux variables at arbitrary nodes
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I'm wondering what the 'best' way to access both variables, and aux variables at some arbitrary node is - for example, at the nearest node on a particular boundary, or a neighbour to the current node. Obtaining the node ID's is not a problem.
I have had some success by setting the coupled variable type to be an integer in the header file, then using this to to get the dof number for that variable at a particular node, and finally pulling the appropriate value out from _nl.sys.currentSolution.
This was an approach I saw in another auxkernel (I'd have to dig around to remember which one!), rather than something I came up with myself.
The problem I am now having is that it doesn't seem to work for aux variables?
When I try and pass in aux variables using the same syntax, the integer associated with them is negative. Even stranger to me, the value doesn't change whether I include the aux variable in the input file or not (it is not a required variable).
All of this makes me think the negative integer values I'm seeing associated with aux variables here are nonsense?
Now I'm wondering two things:


Are aux variables also stored in currentSolution, or are they dealt with differently? Is there a way I can access their values at a specific node?


Is there a conventional way of doing this in general? So far I have been using a method from another aux kernel, but perhaps this isn't the intended/best method for achieving this?


Hopefully the problem makes sense - if anything needs clarification, please let me know.
Thanks!

Hello
auxiliary variables should be in the auxiliary system solution not the _nl
I can look for them later but this has been a fairly common need and there s at least another post about this on this forum.
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume, thanks for the quick response!
I have been looking on the forum but so far haven't found anything looking specifically at aux variables at nodes besides the current node. If you do happen to know of any threads I should take a look at, these are very welcome (and apologies if this turns out to be a duplicate!).
Thanks for pointing out the different systems - I'll look at the auxiliary system documentation to try and get the right syntax.
Negative integers (in my head, I'm expecting these to represent an index?) associated with the aux variables still seems strange, but I could be misunderstanding what's going on behind the scenes, and what these values represent?
Even stranger is the fact they don't change, whether I do or don't pass in a variable from the input file, so I think I must be totally going wrong in this part.
Just in case I've done something daft in the code, I have const int _myAuxVar in the header file, then params.addCoupledVar("myAuxVar") and _myAuxVar(coupled("myAuxVar")) in the class definition and initialiser list in the .C file.

This is the index of the variable.
You need to use coupledValue() to get the value at the local qp/node (for a nodal variable)

Thank you for clarifying.
I believe I do want the index of my aux variables, rather than the value in order to subsequently get the value at some other node, besides the local node/qp.
Printing the value of the index, I am seeing '-1' and '-2' for my two auxvariables.
Attempting to use these in, say, someNode->dof_number(_aux_sys.number(), myVarIndex, 0) results in a segfault (Which I think is expected, given the index seems wrong).
As a check, replacing 'myVarIndex' with '0', runs with no segfault (although I don't know which variable this corresponds to).
I think there are two questions from this:
1) Is it possible to use coupledValue() to get the variable at node besides the local node/qp? This would allow me to take a different approach entirely. EDIT: I thought this part had been answered previously, and found the thread - I believe the coupled interface only allows you to access local values?

Should the index be negative for auxvariables? If not, have I done something wrong in declaring these as described above?

Thanks

coupledValue should only give the local value
i suspect not but I dont see how we handle auxiliary variables in this code
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/classCoupleable.html#ae04c38300772a77cd4632168742eea80

so I think this needs a patch.
Other threads about this
#21907
your own comment here
#22895 (reply in thread)

Ah yes - using unsigned int rather than int, I get the max possible integer minus 1 or 2, so it's definitely hitting that last line from https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/moose/classCoupleable.html#ae04c38300772a77cd4632168742eea80 as you suggested.
As a workaround in the meantime, it seems I can subtract the number returned from numeric_limits....etc....max() to get back to var->number().
The comment in the code you linked to suggests that generally, this could cause bad jacobians. Are we safe to do this in the context of aux kernels, since these do not have a residual contribution?
Thanks for your help!
yeah dont worry about the bad jacobian message, that s for another context
Noted, thanks!

Hey @Eilloo  I was wondering how did you used your method for accessing variables at nodes near to boundary ? I am also trying to do the same for variables whose values are stored in current solution (global vector) and using DOF map to find their information. Can you please guide me or provide an example where you looked at for your case.

did you try to use the coupleable interface first? This is the preferred way
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/include/interfaces/Coupleable.h
Is this method for getting values of nodal variables or elemental variables ?
I want to get value of Temperature (Nodal variables) for local nodes in my mesh and also for non local nodes ?

it does either, depending on the type of loop the object is in
is this for. am material? a kernel?
This is for kernel (heat conduction equation) for temperature variable
kernels use quadrature point based loop, not node. So coupledValue would give the value of the variable at each quadrature point
Oh this was not aware of, do you have any idea, for the case of nodes. What method I can use to get the value of Temperature
why do you need nodal values?

So basically I am using XFEM for a moving interface in my system. In XFEM, moving interface is defined by a level set based user object. I need to get the nodal values like T present on each node ID, so that I can customize the level set user object based on the information regarding Temperature on nodes so that XFEM can access those nodal values and track the moving interface accordingly. For that reason first step I am struggling with is to get the global solution vector. I came across this forum I thought with this method I can access nodal values

if you know the node you need the value on, you can do node->dof_number(system number, variable number, 0)
to get the index into the solution vector

you get the solution vector usually from doing  _solution(_sys.solution()), in the constructor's initializer's list
you get _sys either because it already exists as an attribute or you can get it from any variable with variable.sys()
Thanks Guillaume for your help, have understood now. Will try it out

node.title: Pressure BC convergence error
node.bodyText:
Hello, I am using Pressure BC with a cohesive zone model and I keep getting convergence problem, is it an issue with the use of this type of boundary condition with the cz model or would it be due to my model parameters? My input file is :
[Mesh]
  [msh]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    xmax = 1
    ymax = 2
    nx = 1
    ny = 2
  []
  [block1]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = 'msh'
    bottom_left = '0 0 0'
    top_right = '1 1 0'
    block_id = 1
    block_name = 'block1'
  []
  [block2]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = 'block1'
    bottom_left = '0 1 0'
    top_right = '1 2 0'
    block_id = 2
    block_name = 'block2'
  []
  [split]
    type = BreakMeshByBlockGenerator
    input = block2
  []
  [top_node]
    type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
    coord = '0 2 0'
    input = split
    new_boundary = top_node
  []
  [bottom_node]
    type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
    coord = '0 0 0'
    input = top_node
    new_boundary = bottom_node
  []
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Physics]
  [SolidMechanics]
    [QuasiStatic]
      generate_output = 'stress_yy'
      [all]
        strain = FINITE
        add_variables = true
        decomposition_method = TaylorExpansion
      []
    []
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [fix_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    preset = true
    value = 0.0
    boundary = bottom_node
    variable = disp_x
  []

  [fix_top]
    type = DirichletBC
    preset = true
    boundary = top
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
  []

[./Pressure]
  [./Side3]
    boundary = top
    function = fux
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  [../]
[]

  [bottom]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = bottom
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
    preset = true
  []
[]

[Functions]
 [./fux]
   type = PiecewiseLinear
   x = '0.0  1'
   y = '0.0  10'
[]
[]

[Physics/SolidMechanics/CohesiveZone]
  [czm_ik]
    boundary = 'interface'
    strain = finite
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  []
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensor
    fill_method = symmetric9
    C_ijkl = '1.684e5 0.176e5 0.176e5 1.684e5 0.176e5 1.684e5 0.754e5 0.754e5 0.754e5'
  []
  [czm]
    type = BiLinearMixedModeTraction
    boundary = 'interface'
    penalty_stiffness = 1e5
    GI_c = 1e3
    GII_c = 1e2
    normal_strength = 10
    shear_strength = 15
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    eta = 2.2
    viscosity = 1e-3
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [smp]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient

  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  line_search = none

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'

  automatic_scaling = true

  nl_max_its = 25
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-6
  dt = 0.1
  end_time = 1.0
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
[]

Hello
can you set preset = false instead of true? This makes it easier to impose the displacement without distorting the mesh too much from the get-go, which can throw off the nonlinear solve
and second can you  please paste the log of the simulation? It might be the LU method failing

I changed the preset to false and the petsc option to:
 [Executioner]
 type = Transient
  solve_type = 'newton'
 petsc_options_iname = ' -pc_hypre_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package  -pc_type  '
 petsc_options_value = ' boomeramg mumps hypre  '
automatic_scaling = true
  dt = 0.1
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-6
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-4
  end_time = 1
[] 

but i still got the same convergence issues
*** Warning, This code is deprecated and will be removed in future versions:
Please update your main.C to adapt new main function in MOOSE framework, see'test/src/main.C in MOOSE as an example of moose::main()'. 



*** Info ***
SolidMechanics Action: selecting 'incremental finite strain' formulation.
Framework Information:
MOOSE Version:           git commit fca5273a0b on 2024-11-13

node.title: Using Vector Variables with User-Defined Number of Components in MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A Navier Stokes is the most appropriate category for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (avoid screenshots if possible, triple back quotes before/after pasted text, etc)

Question
Hello everyone, and Happy New Year!
In the MOOSE NS Module, I noticed that density, temperature, and velocity are typically declared as independent variables. I understand this approach provides greater flexibility. However, for tightly coupled systems of PDEs, such as the compressible Navier-Stokes equations, this requires repeatedly declaring couplings for nearly every kernel, material property, etc., which seems suboptimal.
I noticed that MOOSE supports LAGRANGE_VEC variables, where the components are inherently coupled. This got me wondering: is it possible for a user to define a vector variable with DIM+2 components (e.g., velocity vector + density + temperature) so that these variables are coupled by default? This would allow implementing the compressible Navier-Stokes equations in their compact form, simplifying variable transformations.
I looked through the forums and example codes but couldn’t find anyone doing this. Is this approach feasible in MOOSE? If so, what would be the pros and cons? How would it effect computational efficiency? Some drawbacks I can think of is reduced efficiency in automatic differentiation, less code flexibility, but there may be others I haven’t considered.
I’d love to hear your thoughts and experiences!
Additional information
No response

@Silverwing747  I think what you are asking for is similar to the phase field model for grain growth, see:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/phase_field/src/kernels/ACGrGrBase.C
A vector of coupled variables is passed to a kernel with coupledValues
then you can have a look at this:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/phase_field/src/kernels/ACGrGrPoly.C
for the calculation of residual, Jacobian and off-diagonal Jacobian using the vector variable.
The function coupledComponents provides the number of components of the vector,
so it's not given a priori, but user-defined in the input file.

Hello ngrilli,
Thank you very much for your prompt response! I appreciate the example you provided and understand how it achieves a user-defined number of variables. However, I believe it does not fully address what I am trying to accomplish.
In the code you referenced: https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/phase_field/src/kernels/ACGrGrPoly.C, I noticed that both the residual and Jacobian functions still return scalar data types.
What I aim to achieve is all variables are truly coupled, such that the residual will return a RealVectorValue and the Jacobian will return a RealTensorValue, with dimensions that are consistent with a user-defined vector size.
Would you happen to know if this is feasible within the framework? Any guidance would be greatly appreciated!
Thank you in advance for your help.

hello
you'll want to look at what ArrayKernels do.
They are usually used when each component of the array follows the same equation, but could be used with different equations for each component too

hello
you'll want to look at what ArrayKernels do. They are usually used when each component of the array follows the same equation, but could be used with different equations for each component too

Hello Guillaume,
Thank you for the suggestion. It's closer to what I want, but I still have a few follow-up questions:

Does ArrayKernels still support the use of ArrayKernelsValues and ArrayKernelsGrad to automatically apply the test and gradient of the test function?
If the answer is yes, what data type does precomputeQpJacobian return for ArrayKernelsGrad? In this context, precomputeQpResidual already returns a RealEigenMatrix, so precomputeQpJacobian should return a 3D matrix, but I am not sure how to assign the data type.
I see when using ArrayKernels, we will need to write separate function for diagonal entry and off-diagonal entry. However, I found it's easier to compute the entire Jacobian matrix together when working with compact form. I am wondering if there is a way to achieve this?

For 1) you ll want to look at the Coupleable interface to see what's implemented


It would be a tensor ideally. MOOSE supports tensors at various orders which should have the generality we need. Here it's a little more complex because array variables use RealEigenVectors iirc as the backend data container.
The "precomputeQp" is a small optimization. You can work with computeQpJacobian instead as most kernels do


You can override the base classes if you want to modify how the assembly is done. I would recommend you follow how it's done in MOOSE now, then when it works you can optimize. There should be quite a few examples of array kernels, though for most each component will have roughly the same equation

Hello Guillaume,
Thank you very much for your detailed response and thoughtful insights. I completely agree with you that it’s ideal to avoid modifying the MOOSE implementation directly.
I wanted to ask for your opinion on the following approach: I could develop a material system to compute and store the residual and Jacobian in vector/matrix form, and then couple it with the kernel system to access the appropriate entries and apply the test functions. This approach would allow me to work with vector and matrix forms while avoiding modifications to the DiagJacobian and OffDiagJacobian implementations. It would also maintain the separation of variables for flexibility.
However, I have a few questions and concerns regarding the implementation of this approach:

Am I correct in assuming that the material system is only called once per Newton iteration? Otherwise, this approach might result in significant repeating computation.
Is there a way to automatically include all variables in the material system when developing a kernel system?
I noticed that MOOSE provides built-in output_properties for material systems, but the default output uses MONOMIAL. Is there a way to change the output to LAGRANGE?

Thank you in advance for your time and guidance. I look forward to hearing your thoughts on this.

The materials are computed once for the residual evaluation and once for the Jacobian evaluation. By once, I mean once per element and quadrature point.
There is an option in the Executioner to compute the residual and Jacobian together, which is mostly used in combination with automatic differentiation.
You need to develop objects, not "systems". But terminology aside I think your idea can work. In fact the residuals are computed as material properties in the Navier Stokes module.

The output of material properties cannot be changed to Lagrange properties because we do not compute material properties at nodes, but rather at quadrature points.
The problem with nodes is that they may be shared by elements from multiple subdomains. This could mean that multiple materials provide different definitions of the same material property for each subdomain around the node.

The materials are computed once for the residual evaluation and once for the Jacobian evaluation. By once, I mean once per element and quadrature point. There is an option in the Executioner to compute the residual and Jacobian together, which is mostly used in combination with automatic differentiation.

Hello Guillaume,
I was wondering if you could point me to a website or example code that demonstrates how to signal the executioner to compute the Jacobian and Residual together. So far, I haven’t been able to find any relevant resources.
I noticed that the Kernel class includes a public function, virtual void computeResidualAndJacobian() override;, and some applications, like INSFVFluxKernel, seem to utilize it. However, I couldn’t find anything in the executioner related to enabling or controlling this functionality.

See the executioner parameters
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/executioners/Steady.html
It s called residual_and_jacobian_together

node.title: RadialAverage hangs sometimes in parallel
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi,
I've been using RadialAverage and have noticed that it sometimes hangs in parallel. I've pasted the input file at the bottom.
When I run this with 32 processes it hangs (mpiexec -np 32 --oversubscribe myapp -i inputfile.i), but when I run this with 36 processes it finishes.
I did some digging around in the RadialAverage code and I believe the issue shows up in the finalize() method. There is a comment: "we assume that we receive as many messages as we send". With some debug prints I found a situation where rank A was listening for a message from rank B, but rank B had not sent any message to rank A.
Any ideas on how to fix this? Or is something else at fault?
filter_radius = 0.1

[Mesh]
  [generated] # Cuboid meshed with HEX8
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    xmin = 0
    xmax = 5
    ymin = 0
    ymax = 2
    zmin = 0
    zmax = 1
    nx = 100
    ny = 40
    nz = 20
    elem_type = HEX8
  []
[]

[Variables]
  [dummy] # some dummy variable and kernel
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [null]
    type = NullKernel
    variable = dummy
  []
[]


[Materials]
  [press] # some material that I want to average
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'pressure'
    prop_values = '1.0'
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  num_steps = 1
  dt = 1.0
  
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-4

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu preonly'

  abort_on_solve_fail = true
[]

[Outputs]
  execute_on = 'timestep_end'
  exodus = true
[]

[UserObjects]
  [radavg] # averaging the material
    type = RadialAverage
    prop_name = "pressure"
    weights = linear
    execute_on = 'timestep_end'
    radius = ${filter_radius}
  []
[]

[Debug]
  show_material_props = true
  show_execution_order = 'linear timestep_end' 
[]

Hello
Thanks for reporting the issue. I don't see why it would hang in finalize, every process would be calling regardless of whether it owns any element. It's just part of the execution workflow, which you could see from  show_execution_order = 'linear timestep_end'.
I will try to replicate the issue. Which platform did you use? Which installation method?
Is there any reason you use --oversubscribe ? We dont expect any performance gain from that in MOOSE
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume, thanks for responding.
Yes every proc will call finalize, but when they are exchanging information there are some receive requests that do not have a corresponding send (line 168 of RadialAverage.C), so some ranks hang waiting for data that will never arrive.
We built MOOSE from source on internal linux-based HPC hardware. We used this version of MOOSE.
I'm using --oversubscribe because originally I was seeing these issues when I was running across multiple cluster nodes. I then made this small test case which hangs with 32 procs. If you're running it on a single machine you might not have 32 cores to run this on so you'll need to oversubscribe.

I could reproduce this on an M4 when oversuscribing and created an issue.
Looking at the code, it seems to be trying to do some optimized communication directly in MOOSE.
If you look at the LayeredAverage/Base code you can see it's much simpler and delegates the communication tasks to TIMPI.
This is likely the fix. With MOOSE-conference coming I wont be able to tackle this for another 2 weeks btw

node.title: Problems growing cracks in 3D
node.bodyText:
I have been trying to grow cracks in 3D geometries on an Apple M1 Max with 32GB memory using the December 2024 version of MOOSE.
QUESTION 1: Are there any demonstrations of growing cracks using the Peridynamics module. I can damage connections and change the number of intact nodes, but not actually extend a crack.
QUESTION 2: Are there any demonstrations of growing cracks using the XFEMRankTwoTensorMarkerUserObject in 3D. I have not been able to initiate secondary cracks or extend a RectangleCutUserObject. The Marker object seems to be insensitive to the threshold parameter.
QUESTION 3: There are 3 demonstrations of growing cracks in the modules/xfem/test/tests/solid_mechanics_basic/ folder, but it is almost impossible to extend the scripts to work on geometriess bigger than 5x5x2. I have also been unable to define more than one crack either within the .xda file or by usinging multiple CrackMeshCut3DUserObject. In the first case, the error was "A fragment boundary edge can't have more than 1 cuts." In the second case, the code crashed my computer by using up all memory.
QUESTION 4: I was able to generalize the edge_crack_3d_propagation script to 10x10x10 and 20 time steps by reducing the size_control parameter and allowing growth in the x, y, and z directions, but with faster growth or longer runs, I would get error "attempting to add edge intersection when one already exists with different node."
QUESTION 5: When I try to extend the in mhs or fatique versions of this script, I get error "the crack front and the tracked crack front definition must match in terms of their end nodes." Or error "Invalid distance r in CrackFrontDefinition::calculateRThetaToCrackFront."
Here is the .xda file I am using to define a single, minimal crack for the 10x10x10 geometry:
libMesh-0.7.0+

-0.001 0.5 0.201
0.401 0.5 -0.001
0.401 0.5 0.0663333
0.401 0.5 0.133667
0.401 0.5 0.201


Here is the code that I used to successfully propagate a predefined crack for 8 time steps in the 10x10x10 geometry. It fails when I try to grow cracks faster or for more time steps, or when I try to make similar changes to the mhs or fatigue versions of the script):
[GlobalParams]

[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic]

@bwspenc for Q1
@lynnmunday and @hugary1995  for Q2-5

I haven't run the 3D xfem cutting object, I've only run 2D simulations.  @jiangwen84 might have some advice.
Smeared cracking works well for damage problems: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ComputeSmearedCrackingStress.html
This osti report shows us getting nice results in 3D for graphite fracture with smeared cracking:
https://www.osti.gov/biblio/2000030

Thank you, I will look into modules/solid_mechanics/test/tests/smeared_cracking to see if any of the scripts can be extended to grow cracks.
The paper you cited shows some excellent results. It says that it was implemented in the Grizzly extension of Moose. Can crack growth be demonstrated in Moose itself?
I look forward to hearing more from @jiangwen84 and others.

I'm beginning to get a idea of how smeared cracking works. There are no topographic cracks. Instead material softening. I imagine that the way the smeared cracking images in the report were generated was by attaching a damage model and somehow creating an image of that. If any examples or the code for the report are available, I would appreciate seeing them.

The color is showing the damage, 0 to 1.  We ran the simulation in Grizzly because Grizzly has some graphite material models for thermal and elastic properties but everything in the Smeared cracking model is available in MOOSE solid_mechanics.  @bwspenc do you have any smeared cracking simulation inputs he could try?

Thank you, @lynnmunday for your prompt and helpful responses. The June 2023 osti report you cited contained a wealth of information about the state of crack modeling in MOOSE and the features that needed to be added at that time. My impression is that Peridynamics and 3D XFEM have limited capabilities for now, so it is best to use 2D XFEM with MeshCut2DFractureUserObject and MeshCut2DRankTwoTensorNucleation and 2 and 3D smeared cracking with a damage model, so I will proceed in those directions.
If anyone (@bwspenc, @jiangwen84, @hugary1995 ?) has more information or sample codes on my original questions or on applying damage models to smeared cracking, I would greatly appreciate them.

If you're interested in XFEM, I would recommend starting with 2D and working your way up to 3D. If you want something to just work out of the box in 2D or 3D, smeared cracking is definitely the way to go in my opinion, as others have said. We have various regression tests, but I'm not sure that we have any larger-scale demo problems in the repository.

QUESTION 1: Are there any demonstrations of growing cracks using the Peridynamics module. I can damage connections and change the number of intact nodes, but not actually extend a crack.

Peridynamics represents fracture by breaking bonds, so there really isn't a description of the exact location of a crack. If you're able to damage connections, it's probably basically working for you.

QUESTION 2: Are there any demonstrations of growing cracks using the XFEMRankTwoTensorMarkerUserObject in 3D. I have not been able to initiate secondary cracks or extend a RectangleCutUserObject. The Marker object seems to be insensitive to the threshold parameter.

That XFEMRankTwoTensorMarkerUserObject does ad-hoc extension of the cracks element by element. That works in 2D, but it isn't readily extensible in 3D. It's not really the best way to do things in 2D either because the stresses at the crack tips are singular, so the results are sensitive to mesh refinement. I would recommend focusing on the mesh-based cutter, which represents the cutting plane by a lower-dimensional mesh and uses fracture integrals. That's reasonably robust in 2D, and much more experimental in 3D.

QUESTION 3: There are 3 demonstrations of growing cracks in the modules/xfem/test/tests/solid_mechanics_basic/ folder, but it is almost impossible to extend the scripts to work on geometriess bigger than 5x5x2. I have also been unable to define more than one crack either within the .xda file or by usinging multiple CrackMeshCut3DUserObject. In the first case, the error was "A fragment boundary edge can't have more than 1 cuts." In the second case, the code crashed my computer by using up all memory.

I guess I'd need to learn more about what wasn't working in going to larger geometries. There are a lot of corner cases, so we do occasionally hit those types of errors that you're seeing. I'm not sure what was going on with it using up memory. There are currently some scalability issues with XFEM regarding memory usage, but we have successfully used it on models up to maybe 1 million nodes.
QUESTION 4: I was able to generalize the edge_crack_3d_propagation script to 10x10x10 and 20 time steps by reducing the size_control parameter and allowing growth in the x, y, and z directions, but with faster growth or longer runs, I would get error "attempting to add edge intersection when one already exists with different node."
You've probably hit another corner case here.
QUESTION 5: When I try to extend the in mhs or fatique versions of this script, I get error "the crack front and the tracked crack front definition must match in terms of their end nodes." Or error "Invalid distance r in CrackFrontDefinition::calculateRThetaToCrackFront."
...and yet another corner case! 3D XFEM is gnarly.
I believe it's possible to work through most of these issues, but it sounds like maybe you're gravitating toward smeared cracking. I would be happy to talk through this with you.
Thank you @bwspenc and @lynnmunday. Your answers have been very helpful. There are still mysteries in 3D XFEM, but I am going to preceed with smeared cracking.

node.title: How to extract the heat for different layers along the cylinder axial?
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I want to extract the heat released for different layers(10 layers for example) along the cylinder axial for future 3d_1d coupling studies.
My first idea is 【1】to use DiffusionFluxAux to calclulate -D∂T/∂n, 【2】use LayeredSideIntegral to calculate the ∫-D∂T/∂n dA for Layer 1, Layer 2,..., Layer 10, and 【3】use SpatialUserObjectVectorPostprocessor to output these values
Another idea seems to be very cumbersome: (1) Use SideSetsFromBoundingBoxGenerator to cut the the side area of the cylinder into 10 layers. (2) Use SideDiffusiveFluxIntegral to extract these heat values ∫-D∂T/∂n dA for Layer 1, Layer 2,..., Layer 10.
So I make an example of heat conduction problem in a cylinder with a cosine distribution heat source. The condtion is as follows:
radius: 0.5[m]; height: 10.0[m]
heat source distribution per unit volume: (2240000)(cos(pi/5(z-5))+1)   (z: [m], source: [W/m3])
outer side boundary condition value: 300.0[K]
thermal_conductivity: 200.0 [W/(m·K)]
The simulation domain is as follows:

The input file is

  [accg]
    type = AdvancedConcentricCircleGenerator
    ring_radii = '0.5'
    ring_intervals = '200'
    ring_block_ids = '15 20'
    ring_block_names = 'inner_tri inner'
    external_boundary_id = 50
    external_boundary_name = 'right'
    num_sectors = 200
    preserve_volumes = True
  []
  
  [extrude1]
    type = AdvancedExtruderGenerator
    input = accg
    heights = 10.0
    num_layers = 10
    direction = '0 0 1'
  []
  
  [ssfbbg1]
    type = SideSetsFromBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = extrude1
    bottom_left = '-0.500001 -0.500001 -1e-05'
    top_right =   ' 0.500001  0.500001 1.00001'
    boundary_new = 'layer_1'
    boundaries_old = 'right'
  []
  [ssfbbg2]
    type = SideSetsFromBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = ssfbbg1
    bottom_left = '-0.500001 -0.500001 0.99999'
    top_right =   ' 0.500001  0.500001 2.00001'
    boundary_new = 'layer_2'
    boundaries_old = 'right'
  []
  [ssfbbg3]
    type = SideSetsFromBoundingBoxGenerator

    bottom_left = '-0.500001 -0.500001 1.99999'

    boundaries_old = 'right'
  []
  [ssfbbg4]

    boundaries_old = 'right'
  []
  [ssfbbg5]

    boundary_new = 'layer_5'
    boundaries_old = 'right'
  []
  [ssfbbg6]
    type = SideSetsFromBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = ssfbbg5
    bottom_left = '-0.500001 -0.500001 4.99999'
    top_right =   ' 0.500001  0.500001 6.00001'
    boundary_new = 'layer_6'
    boundaries_old = 'right'
  []
  [ssfbbg7]
    type = SideSetsFromBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = ssfbbg6
    bottom_left = '-0.500001 -0.500001 5.99999'
    top_right =   ' 0.500001  0.500001 7.00001'
    boundary_new = 'layer_7'
    boundaries_old = 'right'
  []
  [ssfbbg8]
    type = SideSetsFromBoundingBoxGenerator

    bottom_left = '-0.500001 -0.500001 6.99999'
    top_right =   ' 0.500001  0.500001 8.00001'
    boundary_new = 'layer_8'
    boundaries_old = 'right'
  []
  [ssfbbg9]
    type = SideSetsFromBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = ssfbbg8
    bottom_left = '-0.500001 -0.500001 7.99999'
    top_right =   ' 0.500001  0.500001 9.00001'
    boundary_new = 'layer_9'

  []
  [ssfbbg10]

    top_right =   ' 0.500001  0.500001 10.00001'
    boundary_new = 'layer_10'
    boundaries_old = 'right'
  []

[]

[Functions]
  [cosinedistribution]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '(2240000)*(cos(pi/5*(z-5))+1)'
  []
[]

[Variables]

    family = LAGRANGE

  []

  [sdfi7]
    type = SideDiffusiveFluxIntegral
    boundary = layer_7

  [sdfi8]

  []
  [sdfi10]

    boundary = layer_10
    variable = temp
    diffusivity = thermal_conductivity
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
[]


The result is

I have some questions:
Is this the best method to extract the heat along the axial by MOOSE team? Are there any more simple ways?
Why there is difference among the result of the theory, idea 1, and idea 2?

Why there is difference among the result of the theory, idea 1, and idea 2?

is this converged in the axial mesh?

Is this the best method to extract the heat along the axial by MOOSE team? Are there any more simple ways?

imo the best method is for you to code a LayeredSideDiffusiveFluxIntegral user object. Then the SpatialUserObjectVPP can be used for output

Haha, this is converged certainly, unless I would not show you results.
LayeredSideDiffusiveFluxIntegral does not exist in current MOOSE version (but LayeredSideDiffusiveFluxAverage instead), maybe I should try to code this by myself...
This is my result also for LayeredSideDiffusiveFluxAverage × side area. Evidently, it has a slight difference...

try refining the mesh to see if you get closer to theory.
This is <1% off, could still be discretization

node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I am facing an error in HPC. When I submit a job like:
#!/bin/bash
#PBS -q parallel
#PBS -j oe
#PBS -N Dec_P12_noGND
#PBS -l select=1:ncpus=20:mpiprocs=20:mem=20GB
#PBS -l walltime=10:00:00
source /etc/profile.d/modules.sh
source /app1/ebenv
module load buildenv/default-foss-2022a CMake/3.23.1-GCCcore-11.3.0 Python/3.10.4-GCCcore-11.3.0 PyYAML/6.0-GCCcore-11.3.0
cd /hpctmp/guozixu/scut/
mpiexec -n 20 ./scut-opt -i Dec_P12.i > Dec_P12_noGND.txt
wait
exit 0
The errors occur as:
./scut-opt: error while loading shared libraries: libsz.so.2: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

However, when I just run
./scut-opt -i Dec_P12.i
at the command window without the parallel, everything goes well.
I can confirm the the opt file is newly complied.
Can you give me some suggestion to solve this issue?

Using ldd on your executable, find which module isnproviding this particular shared library.
Then make sure it's loaded in your run script
I suspect the difference is between the compute nodes and the login node, not between parallel and serial

node.title: Model does not calculate the expected porepressure gradient
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I would like to simulate a hydro-mechanical groundwater model investigating on land subsidence due to groundwater abstraction. In a first step, I want to build a steady state model without abstracting any water. My model contains 5 layers (3 aquifers and 2 aquitards, find more information below). Since the upper aquifer is not confined, I use the PorousFlowUnsaturated model. I would like to get groundwater flow from my inflow boundary condition (DirichletBC on left side) to my outflow boundary condition (DirichletBC on right side). However, no matter how I adjust the boundary conditions, either I don’t get a flow between inflow and outflow or the model does not converge. I already tried to set the boundary conditions as Dirichlet BCs and as PorousFlowPiecewiseLinearSink boundary conditions as quasi Dirichlet BCs, but nothing worked out.
My model contains 5 layers. From top to bottom:

OGWL: partially unsaturated;  on the left side is set a higher hydraulic head then on the right side
OZH: aquitard; no flow is defined
MGWL: confined aquifer; a hydraulic head is set only on the left side; a no flow is defined on the right side
UZH: aquitard; no flow is defined
UGWL: confined aquifer; a hydraulic head is set only on the left side; a no flow is defined on the right side

The boundary conditions are defined as depth-dependent (z-direction) functions of porepressures using an if-condition to set the hydraulic head at the left and right BC. The solver is a transient solver modelling steadystate conditions.
Especially for the OGWL I expect a gradient and different porepressure values at the boundaries left and right. Above the hydraulic heads set for OGWL I expect the porepressure values to be zero, but instead they are negative. My model does not converge. I get really high positive linear and non linear residuals. When I model the OGWL to be completely dry, the model converges easily. So somehow the modelling of the partially unsaturated layer seems not to work.
In order to avoid complex effects and accelerate test runs, I built up a smaller hydraulic test model with the same setup and set boundary conditions. This model is converging. Unfortunately:

The porepressure values on the left and right boundary are the exact same value. I receive an unrealistic porepressure distribution.
The flow velocity in x-direction shows a groundwater flow from the center of the model to the left and right boundaries, instead of a flow from the left to the right boundary
The porepressure values above water table are still negative. To solve this problem I added at the top of the model a porepressure = 0 boundary condition, but then a vertical gradient with positive porepressure values is calculated. That's also unexpected cause there should be no water at all, so the porepressure values should be zero.

I attached my mesh and input file for my test model. small-model.zip
Any ideas how to get a correct porepressure gradient are very welcomed and highly appreciated.
Thanks in advance!

Hello
I recommend building the input file step by step, this is a little complicated.

linear and non-linear residuals are getting negative

they are getting small and close to 0 if converging. Not negative

The porepressure values on the left and right boundary are the exact same value.

this looks like a problem with the setup

The porepressure values above water table are still negative. To solve this problem I turned on the top boundary condition (which sets the top surface of the model to zero porepressure), but then a vertical gradient with positive porepressure values is calculated. That's also unexpected cause there should be no water at all, so the porepressure values should be zero.

an alternative to explore might be setting a Bound on the porepressure.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/bounds/ConstantBounds.html
OR not solving for porepressure above the water table using a block restriction of the variable

Hi
Thanks for Answering! Yes you're right about

they are getting small and close to 0 if converging. Not negative.

I meant the exponents of my residuals are getting negative, so they are near zero.
And I already tried to build up the input file step by step, but I still have no clue what's wrong.
Thanks for the idea to set a Bound on porepressure! I will try this.

Hi,
I tried to set a Bound on porepressure but either a second variable is needed or MOOSE doesn't find the ConstantBounds "Feature". Do I have to install it seperately?

Hi,
Since you are running SS, I assume you want to saturate every layer except the top one. Use high conductivity for all layers to avoid convergence issues caused by low permeability. After reaching SS, adjust the value to the real one. Also, try setting your pp at the bottom of the model. If you want flow from left to right, set pp at the bottom nodes of your boundary.
If you need a thunder pressure distribution over depth, set pp at the bottom nodes of each layer. If your mesh is too complex to extract those nodes, you can use a more advanced mesher like LaGriT, which allows for these types of adjustments.

Hi,
Thanks for Answering!

If you want flow from left to right, set pp at the bottom nodes of your boundary.

But when I do it that way, I don't get the OGWL partially unsaturated. Or should I set it additionally?

Hi,
Im not sure if I understand the question. If you set, for example, 8m head at the bottom of your boundary and your model is 10m depth you will have 2m of unsaturated zone. Makes sense?

Hi,
ahh, yes, now I understand. Thank you!

Hi,
do you have coincidentally an idea how I could get physical curves in Gmsh, that are not only saved as geometrical entities? Cause I can only set at this curves a porepressure, when MOOSE recognizes them. And for this, the physical curves in Gmsh needs to be saved as mesh entities. I also wanted to try it with LaGriT but I don't understand how to download it.
If not, it is no problem. I just thought maybe you have worked with Gmsh earlier.

Hi,
Yes, libmesh wont recognize every entity of gmsh. What I would try is to code a python script which looks for the entities in your .msh file and extract the nodes you are interested with some kind of condition (e.g. node value == datum). Then you can set the BC  in moose manually or with a script.
  [nodes]
    input = my_mesh
    type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
    new_boundary = my_nodes
    coord = '0 0 0; 0 0 1' # extracted nodes here
  []

With lagrit is a bit easier, but also not fully automated.

Hi,
thank you for your help! I managed to extract the nodes with python, but I have problems to add a new boundary in MOOSE.
My Code is:

But I get the error: Task add_mesh_generator is not registered to build MooseMesh derived objects
And when I try it with [Sets] and boundary_set, I get the errors:
parameter 'Sets/boundary_set/type' supplied multiple times
parameter 'Sets/boundary_set/boundary' supplied multiple times
Do you have an idea, how to circumvent or solve these errors?
You need to create a FileMeshGenerator not a FileMesh
And delete this Actions block and nest the two ExtraNodesetGfenerator under the Mesh block
Thank youu! Now it's calculating :D

unlike #25694, my simulation is not dynamic. I am simulating thermo-hydro-mechanical behavior of geothermal reservoir due to the injection so the response of the model would be in quasi-static.
I have tried with short time step e.g. 60s while it was 86400. the attempt was unsuccessful.
also i have tried all explicit methods in MOOSE which were unsucessful. here is the "Excutioner"

  [../]

even if it's quasi static you need to get the time step size below that number it requires.
I ll add a log to make it easier to find, but try dt = 0.1 etc
actually you can set the min step size to this material using the "min_step_size" parameter. This might let you increase it

Hi @GiudGiud
I just ran it successfuuly.
I used a trick to run it in palsticity. first  I ran the model in elastic regime to reach steady state then I used "SolutionUserObject" to initialise the plastic set up with the results of the elastic results to proceed the simulation in plastic regime.
Now it goes well but with short time step size.
